1. Customer Lifetime Value (CLV)

Definition: Customer lifetime value (CLV) is a metric that estimates the total revenue a business can expect to earn from a single customer over the course of their lifetime.

How to use it: CLV can be used to determine how much a business should be willing to spend on acquiring new customers or retaining existing ones. By understanding the value of each customer, a business can prioritize its marketing efforts and allocate resources more effectively.

Advantages: CLV provides businesses with a clear understanding of the long-term value of each customer, which can inform important decisions related to marketing, customer acquisition, and customer retention. By focusing on customer lifetime value, businesses can develop more effective marketing strategies that are geared towards long-term success.

Textbook reference: Kotler, P., & Keller, K. L. (2016). Marketing Management (15th ed.). Pearson.

2. Attribution Modelling

Definition: Attribution modelling is a way of measuring the impact of different marketing channels on the customer journey, by assigning credit for conversions to each touchpoint in the journey.

How to use it: Attribution modelling can help businesses understand which marketing channels are most effective in driving conversions, and how those channels work together to influence customer behavior. By analyzing the customer journey and assigning credit to each touchpoint, businesses can optimize their marketing spend and improve the effectiveness of their campaigns.

Advantages: Attribution modelling provides businesses with a more accurate understanding of the impact of their marketing efforts, and can help them make more informed decisions about where to allocate resources. By understanding the customer journey and how different touchpoints influence behavior, businesses can develop more effective marketing strategies that are geared towards driving conversions.

Textbook reference: Dave Chaffey, Fiona Ellis-Chadwick, Richard Mayer, Kevin Johnston, and Mathew Sweezey. (2021). Digital Marketing Excellence: Planning, Optimizing and Integrating Online Marketing (7th ed.). Routledge.

3. Social Listening

Definition: Social listening is the process of monitoring social media channels for mentions of a brand, product, or service, and analyzing the data to gain insights into customer sentiment, preferences, and behavior.

How to use it: Social listening can help businesses understand how their brand is perceived by customers, what customers are saying about their products or services, and how they can improve the customer experience. By monitoring social media channels and analyzing the data, businesses can identify trends and opportunities to engage with customers in a more meaningful way.

Advantages: Social listening provides businesses with real-time insights into customer behavior and sentiment, which can inform important decisions related to product development, marketing, and customer service. By listening to customers and responding to their needs, businesses can build stronger relationships and increase customer loyalty.

Textbook reference: Tuten, T. L., & Solomon, M. R. (2017). Social Media Marketing (3rd ed.). Sage Publications.

4. A/B Testing

Definition: A/B testing is a method of comparing two versions of a web page, email, or other marketing asset to determine which version performs better.

How to use it: A/B testing can help businesses optimize their marketing assets by testing different variables, such as headlines, images, or calls-to-action, and measuring the impact on customer behavior. By testing different versions of a marketing asset, businesses can identify which version performs better and make data-driven decisions about which version to use.

Advantages: A/B testing provides businesses with a scientific approach to marketing optimization, allowing them to make data-driven decisions that improve customer engagement and drive conversions. By continually testing and optimizing their marketing assets, businesses can improve the effectiveness of their campaigns and achieve better results over time.

Textbook reference: Eisenberg, B., Davis, J., & Diaz, L. (2017). Buyer
